"720p is just double of what I do, so the filesize have be double of it" 
@MKVGuy - I think there's something wrong with your computation..

MKVGuy encode  : 640x272=174,080 pixels
                 720p : 1280x544=696,320 pixels 

696,320/174,080= 4 

720p(1280x544) has 4 times more pixels than your encode(640x272), so you need 4 times more bitrate. :)

@ ninjaracoon

You are not entirely right
Bitrate does not depend entirely on Resolution ....... It depends upon length of the movie & types of graphics used in the movie as well

Increasing Bitrate 4 times may very well result in a good quality Rip but it will increase the size also & sometimes a judicial use of Bitrate can result in a good quality rip at a very attractive size

I'm just correcting mkvguy that 1280x544 is exacly 4 times bigger than 640x272 not twice like he said : "720p is just double of what I do". that's a fact.

"Increasing Bitrate 4 times may very well result in a good quality Rip but it will increase the size also & sometimes a judicial use of Bitrate can result in a good quality rip at a very attractive size "
@riddlerA - yeah it also depends on the complexity of the source, 
and quality is very subjective.. IMHO a 720p film(non anime) with 1mbps bitrate looks sub-720p not a real HD,looks washout, but that's just me :)
